title-group.article-title: CD25 Is a Novel Marker of Hepatic Bile Canaliculus

article-meta.aff: 1Hepatology Research Institute, Contagious Hospital, Wuxi, Jiangsu Province, China
2Maternity & Child Care Center, Wuxi, Jiangsu Province, China
3Fudan University Shanghai Medical School, Shanghai, China
4The First Affiliated Hospital, Nanjing Medical University, Nanjing, China

author-notes.corresp: Zhong-Hua Lu, Hepatology Research Institute, Wuxi Contagious Hospital, Xingyuan Zhong Road 88, Wuxi, Jiangsu Province, 214005, China Email: lu_z_h@126.com

abstract.p: Objective. Although many antigens have been investigated, the method for the bile canaliculus staining using optical microscopy needs to be improved. The aim of the present study was to assess the expression pattern of a candidate marker, CD25, in normal and diseased liver tissue. Methods. Immunohistochemistry, immunofluorescence, and immune electron microscopy assays were performed with 41 liver sections and 2 different anti-CD25 monoclonal antibodies. A polyclonal antibody against carcinoembryonic antigen (CEA) was also used to stain bile canaliculus as a control. CD25 expression levels in normal and diseased liver tissue were also determined. Results. CD25 was predominantly localized at the bile canaliculus of adult and infantile liver, evidenced by both immunohistochemistry and immunofluorescence assays. The electron microscopy assay showed that there were obvious amorphous electron-dense deposits at the bile canaliculus. In contrast, the CEA-positive area included bile canaliculus as well as basolateral aspects of hepatocytes. CD25 expression levels did not differ significantly among different disease states. Conclusion. This study provides the first evidence that CD25 is a novel marker of bile canaliculus. Characteristics of CD25 expression may shed light on immunohistochemistry and immunofluorescence analysis of bile canaliculus in both basic and clinical hepatic investigations.

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p: The liver plays an active role in the clearance of systemic endotoxins. Hepatocytes are polarized epithelial cells that make up 70% to 80% of the liver’s cytoplasmic mass. Hepatocytes have distinct structural features representative of their apical domain. Bile canaliculus are approximately 0.7 to 0.8 µm in diameter,1 and are formed by the apposing membranes of contiguous hepatocytes. They are delimited by tight-junction complexes. Paracellular exchange is permitted between plasma and the canaliculus.2 The bile canaliculi merge and form bile ductules, which eventually become the common hepatic duct. In the internal wall of bile canaliculus, there are many canalicular microvilli, which are about 0.5 to 1.0 µm long and 0.1 µm in diameter, that contain arrays of actin filaments and extend from the plasma membrane surface into the canalicular space.2 The bile ducts not only represent pipelines of bile acid but also may dynamically contribute to liver functions.2 Bile formation at the canalicular membrane is a delicate process and malfunction of bile canaliculi may have devastating consequences and lead to the development of liver disease.3 Therefore, illustrating or identifying bile canaliculus using microscopy is very important in liver diseases studies.

More than 40 years ago, enzyme histochemists incubated microtome sections of mammalian liver with ATP and lead (Gomori reaction) and observed a lead phosphate precipitation that identified the “chicken-wire” appearance of the bile canaliculus.4 After its invention, electron microscopy was thought to be the best method for illustrating bile canaliculus.5,6 However, as electron microscopy is difficult to perform, the most common morphological method for lab investigation of tissue remains immunochemistry or immunofluorescence assays. Many antigens, including carcinoembryonic antigen (CEA),7,8 F-actin,9 bile salt transporter (BSEP),10,11 organic anion transporter (MRP2),12 and phosphatidylcholine transporter (MDR1 or MDR3)10 have been used to indicate bile canaliculus in diverse publications. However, the method for the bile canaliculus staining using optical microscopy needs to be improved.

CD25 is the α chain of the interleukin-2 (IL-2) receptor and is expressed on activated T cells, activated B cells, some thymocytes, myeloid precursors, and oligodendrocytes that associate with CD122 to form a heterodimer that can act as a high-affinity receptor for IL-2 (IL-2R).13-15 IL-2R consists typically of 3 receptor subunits named IL-2Rα (CD25), IL-2Rβ (CD122), and the common gamma chain (γc, CD132). It is believed that CD122 and γc are crucial for signal transduction of IL-2, whereas CD25 is nonessential for IL-2 signaling but instead confers high-affinity binding of IL-2 to its receptor, thereby increasing receptor affinities by approximately 100-fold.13,14 CD25 is mainly expressed in a portion of the activated immune cells, especially in regular T cells, in certain forms of lymphoid neoplasia and select autoimmune diseases, and in individuals rejecting allografts.13 Given this natural link between CD25 and the immune system, studies on CD25 in liver have mainly focused on the role of CD25+ T regular cells in chronic viral hepatitis, autoimmune hepatitis, and liver transplantation.16 In fact, numerous reports suggest that CD25 is a critical marker for systemic regulatory T cells.17,18 However, research results regarding the expression of CD25 in hepatic cells are largely unclear.

Here, we assess the potential of CD25 as a novel marker of bile canaliculus via immunochemistry, immunofluorescence, and immune electron microscopy assays. We also investigated hepatic CD25 expression levels in tissue from patients diagnosed with liver disease and normal specimens. Additionally, we studied the expression of CD122 in bile canaliculus. CD122 is also known as IL-2Rβ and coordinately with IL-2 signaling pathway transduction.

sec.title: Reagents
sec.p: The EnVision kit was purchased from Dako (Glostrup, Denmark). The 2 mouse anti-CD25 monoclonal antibodies were purchased from Labvision (clone IL2R.1, Fremont, CA) and Zymed (clone 4c9, South San Francisco, CA). The rabbit anti-CD122 polyclonal antibody was purchased from Abcam (Cambridge, UK). The rabbit anti-carcinoembryonic antigen (p-CEA) polyclonal antibody was purchased from Zymed (South San Francisco, CA). FITC-conjugated goat mouse anti-IgG was purchased from Jackson ImmunoResearch (West Grove, PA).

sec.title: Samples
sec.p: Sections used in this study were from tissue procured during liver biopsy at our hospital from 2005 to 2007, and included 20 hepatitis B patients (n = 3 in Scheuer G1 stage; n = 4 in Scheuer G2 stage; n = 9 in Scheuer G3 stage; n = 4 in Scheuer G4 stage19), 10 patients with primary biliary cirrhosis, 5 patients with drug-induced hepatitis, and 2 patients with chronic rejection after liver transplantation. Biopsies were originally collected to aid in the diagnosis of liver disease, to assess the severity of known liver disease, or to monitor the progress of treatment. Paraffin sections were stored at −80°C for years. Two normal liver tissues were obtained from previously healthy organ donors for liver transplantation. Two infantile liver tissues were obtained from Wuxi Women and Children Hospital. Written informed consent was obtained from individual patients and the experimental protocol was approved by the hospital’s ethic committee.

sec.title: Immunohistochemistry
sec.p: Immunohistochemical analysis was conducted as described previously.20,21 Briefly, liver tissues were fixed in 10% neutral buffered formalin for more than 24 hours. Tissues were processed for routine histopathological examination by dehydrating in a sequence of 50%, 70%, 95%, and 100% ethanol and then embedded in paraffin and 5-µm thick histologic sections were prepared with a Leica CM1900 microtome (Leica Microsystems, Wetzlar, Germany). Paraffin was removed with xylene, and tissues were equilibrated in Tris-buffered saline (TBS). Heat-mediated antigen retrieval (HMAR) was performed using a domestic pressure cooker. Endogenous peroxidase was blocked with hydrogen peroxide (0.5% in methanol) for 15 minutes. To block nonspecific binding, slides were incubated for 1 hour at room temperature in TBS containing 2% (w/v) normal goat serum. Incubation with primary antibodies (mouse anti-CD25 monoclonal antibody, clone IL2R.1, 1:200; mouse anti-CD25 monoclonal antibody, clone 4c9, 1:200; rabbit anti-CD122 polyclonal antibody, 1:200; rabbit anti-carcinoembryonic antigen [p-CEA] polyclonal antibody, 1:200) was carried out in a humidified chamber overnight at 4°C. Slides were rinsed and incubated for 1 hour at room temperature then with EnVision A solution for 20 minutes, and then washed 3 times in PBS. Slides were then rinsed and incubated at room temperature for 30 minutes with EnVision B solution. After the DAB staining, tissues were counterstained with hematoxylin and dehydrated. Negative controls were obtained in each instance by omitting the primary antibody. Micrographs were taken using a Leica DM LB2 microscopic lens.

sec.title: Immunofluorescence
sec.p: The immunofluorescence assay was performed as described previously.22,23 Briefly, 5 µm thick coronal sections were blocked by 1% bovine serum albumin (BSA) for 30 minutes after which they were incubated overnight at 4°C with a single anti-CD25 (1: 200) antibody. After being washed in PBS 3 times, they were incubated with FITC-conjugated goat mouse anti-IgG (Jackson Immunoresearch, West Grove, PA) at room temperature for 30 minutes. The sections were visualized with a fluorescence microscope (465-495 nm), and images were captured.

sec.title: Immunoelectron Microscopy
sec.p: Immunoelectron microscopy analysis was performed as described previously.24 After immunohistochemistry staining, sections for immunoelectron microscopic immunohistochemistry were postfixed in 1% osmium tetroxide for 1 hour, and dehydrated through graded alcohol and propylene oxide (50% alcohol–70% alcohol–80% alcohol–90% alcohol–90% alcohol plus 90% propylene oxide–absolute propylene oxide). Then, the sections were embedded in epoxide resin. Ultrathin sections (50 nm) were cut on a Leica Ultramicrotome (Leica, Deerfield, IL). They were stained by lead citrate and examined on in a Hitachi H-500 electron microscope. Control sections were processed in parallel, in which the primary antibody was either omitted or preabsorbed with the corresponding antigen.

sec.title: Statistical Analysis
sec.p: Data are expressed as mean ± standard deviation (SD). The average optical density (OD) of every section was determined with Image J software (NIH, version 1.4). Differences were evaluated using the Mann–Whitney U test (SPSS, versiom 7.0, Chicago, IL). Statistical significance was set at P < .05.

sec.title: Immunohistochemistry Analysis of CD25
sec.p: Liver sections immunostained with the 2 different mouse anti-CD25 monoclonal antibodies (clone numbers: IL2R.1 and 4c9) generated similar results. No positive cells were observer in the negative controls (in which the primary antibody was omitted). As shown in Figure 1A (200×) and 1B (400×), the tube-like bile canaliculi were clearly stained when either monoclonal antibody was used (blue arrow).

caption.p: CD25 and carcinoembryonic antigen (CEA) immunostaining of bile canaliculus

(A) A canalicular staining pattern was observed after immunohistochemistry with a mouse anti-CD25 monoclonal antibody (clone IL2R.1, 1:200, Labvision). Magnification, 200× (blue arrow). (B) A similar canalicular staining pattern was also observed after immunohistochemistry with a different mouse anti-CD25 monoclonal antibody (clone 4c9, 1:200, Zymed). Magnification: 400× (blue arrow). (C) Liver tissue immunostained for CEA using a polyclonal antibody (1:200, Zymed). Blue arrows indicate the basolateral aspects of hepatocytes. Magnification: 200×.

sec.p: Immunochemistry was also conducted using the p-CEA antibody. As shown in Figure 1C (200×), positive brown staining was observed among tube-like bile canaliculi as well as basolateral aspects of hepatocytes (blue arrows).

We also observed the CD25 expression in infants and children. In the liver tissue obtained from a 26-week gestation fetus, CD25 expression in bile canaliculi was rather weak (Figure 2; 200×). In liver tissues obtained from neonate, CD25 expression was apparent in bile canaliculi (Figure 3; 200×).

caption.p: In the liver tissue obtained from a 26-week gestation fetus, CD25 expression in bile canaliculi was rather weak. Magnification: 200× (blue arrow)
In liver tissues obtained from a neonate, CD25 expression was apparent in bile canaliculi. Magnification: 200× (blue arrow)

sec.title: Immunohistochemistry Analysis of CD122
sec.p: We also studied the expression of CD122, the β chain of IL-2R. CD122 was expressed widely in liver tissue (Figure 4; 200×) and the specificity was scarce.

caption.p: The expression of rabbit anti-CD122(1:200, Abcam), the β chain of IL-2R. CD122 expression in bile canaliculi was rather dull (blue arrow) and the specificity was scarce (green arrow). Magnification: 200×

sec.title: Immunofluorescence Analysis of CD25
sec.p: Immunofluorescence analysis was also performed on adjacent sections. As showed in Figure 5A (200×) and 5B (400×), incubation with either mouse anti-CD25 monoclonal antibody (clone number: IL2R.1 or 4c9) resulted in clear positive staining (green) of the tube-like bile canaliculi (blue arrow).

caption.p: Immunofluorescent staining of bile canaliculus using 2 different anti-CD25 monoclonal antibodies

Similar canalicular staining patterns were revealed by immunofluorescence assay using 2 different mouse anti-CD25 monoclonal antibodies: (A) clone IL2R.1, 1:200, Labvision, magnification: 200× (blue arrow); (B) clone 4c9, 1:200, Zymed, magnification: 400× (blue arrow).

sec.title: Ultrastructure Analysis of CD25
sec.p: Analysis by electron microscopy revealed an obvious amorphous electron-dense deposit at the bile canaliculus (indicated by blue arrows, Figure 6).

caption.p: A representative electron micrograph with an obvious amorphous electron-dense deposit at the bile canaliculi. Magnification: 6000× (blue arrows)

sec.title: CD25 Expression and Liver Disease
sec.p: We analyzed hepatic CD25 expression levels in bile canaliculi of liver tissues collected from normal patients and those diagnosed with one of several liver diseases. CD25 expression did not differ significantly with disease state (Figure 7).

caption.p: Expression levels of CD25 in normal and diseased liver tissues. Each data point represents the CD25 level of a patient. No significant differences in expression were observed

sec.title: Discussion
sec.p: In the present study, we provide evidence that CD25 is a good marker of bile canaliculus. To the best of our knowledge, this is the first study to identify CD25 as a marker of bile canaliculus. Moreover, we observed no differences in CD25 expression in bile canaliculus among liver tissues from patients with diverse liver diseases and normal specimens. Thus, CD25 could be a very useful candidate antigen for immunochemistry and immunofluorescence analyses of bile canaliculus in both basic and clinical hepatic investigations.

Currently, several antigens have been used to identify bile canaliculus. Among these antigens, CEA has been the most accepted. As early as the 1979s and 1980s, an anti-CEA polyclonal antibody (p-CEA) yielded bile canalicular staining in normal liver tissues and hepatic carcinomas.8,25,26 Up to now, numerous reports have used the p-CEA as an important tool to view the bile canaliculus.7,27-29 The phenomenon was thought to be mediated by the cross-reactivity between CEA and biliary glycoprotein8 or canalicular bile acid transporter/ecto-ATPase/cell CAM 105, which is a vital transporter located at the bile canaliculus.30,31 However, some reports also demonstrate CEA staining in non-bile canaliculus locations. Sentani et al32 reported that p-CEA staining in liver could display a cytoplasmic pattern. In our study, we compared CD25 and CEA staining in normal liver tissues. In agreement with Sentani et al,32 we found that CEA was located not only at the bile canaliculus but also at some hepatic sinusoids. Thus, we think the nonspecific expression pattern of CEA may cause some inaccuracies in liver and biliary tract investigations.

In contrast, CD25 was mainly located at the bile canaliculus, which suggests that it may be a more specific and effective marker of bile canaliculus in immunohistochemistry and immunofluorescence analyses. Studies investigating the expression pattern of CD25 in liver are few. Some scholar found that CD25 (IL-2Rα) was expressed by endothelial cells in other organs. Ponsioen et al33 characterized the composition of the mononuclear infiltrate in bile canaliculus of primary sclerosing cholangitis. They did not find any signs of activation of the lymphocytic infiltrate of CD25 in liver sections.33 However, Davenport et al34 showed CD25 immunoreactive lymphocytes in liver and the biliary tree in extrahepatic biliary atresia. The cause of this discrepancy is not clear. In our study, we scarcely observed CD25-positive hepatocytes or lymphocyte infiltration in hepatocytes. In contrast, most CD25-labeled cells were densely distributed in the tube-like bile canaliculus. Moreover, in liver tissues from patients with hepatitis B, primary biliary cirrhosis, drug-induced hepatitis, infantile liver tissues, and chronic rejection after liver transplantation, there may be a large degree of lymphocytic infiltration. However, we did not find many CD25 positive cells among hepatocytes, and CD25 staining was limited to bile canaliculus, similar to our observations in normal liver tissue. Therefore, our results exclude CD25 staining in bile canaliculus as the consequence of an inflammatory liver disease. We also did not find any differences in the density of CD25 staining among normal liver tissue and tissue from several different disease states, excluding the possibility of a confounding influence from hepatic infection. Thus, we believe CD25 is a promising marker of bile canaliculus.

Collectively, data support the conclusion that CD25 is a novel marker for bile canaliculus, and it can be used intensively in immunohistochemistry or immunofluorescence assays in both basic and clinical hepatic studies.
